oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Belle Boyd
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Carte de visite of Confederate spy Belle Boyd
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Women; Spies; Spying

United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865; Tennessee - History -- Civil War, 1861-1865; United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865 -- Participation, Female; United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865 -- Women; Espionage
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Isabelle Marie Boyd (1844-1900) was a Confederate spy who operated from her father's hotel in Front Royal, Virginia. In one instance, she provided valuable information to General Stonewall Jackson during his attack on Union troops in Front Royal. She was arrested several times. She made her way to England in 1864 and returned to the U. S. in 1866.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Aunt Lizzie" Aiken
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Eliza N. "Aunt Lizzie" Atherton Aiken (1817-1906)
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Women; Medical personnel; Nurses

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Born in Auburn, New York, she married Cyrus Aiken in 1837 & they moved to Illinois. She enlisted as a nurse with the Sixth Illinois Cavalry near the beginning of the Civil War. She would later care for Union soldiers at Ovington Hospital in Memphis, Tennessee. She was friends with Mary A. ""Mother"" Sturges.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Three women from the Scobey family at the McGavock Confederate Cemetery during the Confederate reunion.

United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865; Tennessee -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865; United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865 -- Women; Confederate cemeteries
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The McGavock Confederate Cemetery is the nation's largest private Confederate cemetery. Located on two acres of the Carnton plantation in Franklin, Tennessee, the cemetery is the burial site for 1481 Confederates killed at the Battle of Franklin. Carnton served as a field hospital during the 1864 battle.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Mary A. Mother Sturges
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Black and white photograph of Mary A. Mother Sturges (sometimes spelled Sturgis) dressed in black and seated in a brocade armchair. She holds a closed copy of Will Carleton's "Farm Ballads" in her hands. The book (perhaps a prop) is closed and title is facing outward toward the camera.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Nurses; Women
Sturges, Mary A., 1809-1892; Aiken, Eliza A. Atherton, 1817-1906; United States. Army. Illinois Cavalry Regiment, 6th (1861-1865)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Mary A. Mother Sturges (sometimes spelled Sturgis) was an Union Army nurse during the Civil War. She enlisted with the 6th Illinois Cavalry and served with Aunt Lizzie Aiken in Memphis, Tennessee, at the Adams Block Hospital. Mary A. Sturges was 51 years old when she enlisted and served for four years. She was mustered out in June of 1865. She received a Union pension. She died in Kansas City, Kansas, December 29, 1892 and is buried in the Oak Grove Cemetery. Her monument was erected by the GAR.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lucy Virginia French portrait
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Lithograph portrait of Lucy Virginia French bet. p. 438 & 439 in "Women of the South Distinguished in Literature" (1865) by Mary Forrest. She is looking directly ahead with her dark curly hair parted in the middle and framing her face. Her lovely dress has wide 3/4-length sleeves with a great deal of lace flowing out of the sleeves and down to her hands. One simple ring is visible on her right hand and she has on drop earrings. There are flowers pinned to her bodice. She has a somewhat symmetrical face.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Women; Authors
French, L. Virginia (Lucy Virginia), 1825-1881; United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865; Tennessee - History -- Civil War, 1861-1865; Authors; Diarists
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: G. R. Hall
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Lucy Virginia Smith French (1825-1881) was born in Accomack County, VA. In 1848, she and her sister moved to Memphis, where they became teachers. While living in Memphis, she began writing for the Louisville Journal under the pen name ""L'Inconnue,"" and in 1852 she became the editor of the Southern Ladies' Book. In 1853, she married Col. John Hopkins French & relocated to McMinnville, Tennessee, where they they had three children, 1 boy and 2 girls. She kept detailed diaries during the Civil War.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Mrs. Lincoln
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Carte de visite of Mary Todd Lincoln. Image appears very similar to photograph taken of her by Matthew B. Brady in his New York, N.Y. studio in 1861. Her head and left arm are in different positions and the chair has been edited out, but the dress and flowers are the same. Her right arm holding the bouquet is also in the same position. See here: http://www.loc.gov/pictures/item/2008680392/
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Women; Presidents' spouses
United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865; Lincoln, Mary Todd, 1818-1882; Presidents' spouses
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Mary Anne Todd Lincoln (1818-1882) was from a prominent Kentucky family. She married Abraham Lincoln in 1842. She was so deeply traumatized by the assassination of her husband and the deaths of three of her four sons that she began behaving very erratically. As a result, her oldest son, Robert Todd Lincoln, had her committed for insanity in 1875. She is buried with her husband in the Lincoln Tomb, Oak Ridge Cemetery, Springfield, Illinois.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: James Emerick Nagy, Nashville Public Schools Collection, Addition, 1723-1985

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Harriet Tubman
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Lithograph of Harriet Tubman (1820?-1913) from the book "Scenes in the Life of Harriet Tubman" by Sarah H. Bradford.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Women; Spies; Spying; Slaves; Fugitive slaves; Slavery; Suffragists; Activists; Women's suffrage; Civil rights; Abolition movement; Abolitionists; Underground railroad system

Tubman, Harriet, 1820?-1913; Slavery; Fugitive slaves; Antislavery movements -- United States; Women abolitionists; United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865; United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865 -- Women; Espionage
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Harriet Tubman was born a slave around 1820 in Dorchester County, MD. She escaped to Philadelphia in 1849. From 1849 to 1860, she returned to the South 19 times and escorted over 300 slaves to freedom. She also became a prominent Abolitionist. During the Civil War, she worked as a nurse, cook, and spy for the Union. After the Civil War, she became actively involved in the women's suffrage movement.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Nashville was occupied by Union troops shortly after Fort Donelson fell on February 16 , 1862. The city remained occupied throughout the rest of the war. The Battle of Nashville (December 15-16, 1864), was the last in a string of defeats for Confederate general John Bell Hood and his Army of Tennessee and was essentially the last major battle in the Western Theater.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: McGavock Confederate Cemetery at Carnton, in Franklin, Tennessee
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: McGavock Confederate Cemetery located on the grounds of the Carnton Plantation, in Franklin, Tennessee. Interred here are 1,500 Confederate soldiers killed during the Battle of Franklin. The graves are organized by states. Adjacent to the cemetery is the McGavock family cemetery.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Cemeteries; Tombs & sepulchral monuments
McGavock Confederate Cemetery (Franklin, Tenn.); McGavock family; Franklin, Battle of, Franklin, Tenn., 1864; McGavock, Caroline E. Winder, 1829-1905; McGavock, John, 1815-1893
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Confederate cemetery located at ""Carnton,"" in Franklin, Tennessee. When John and Carrie McGavock lived in the home in 1864, it served as a field hospital during the Battle of Franklin. After the war, in 1866, the McGavocks set aside two acres of land on the property so that 1,500 Confederate soldiers could be reinterred there. This cemetery is the largest privately held Confederate cemetery in the United States. Soldiers from all Confederate states, except Virginia, are buried in the cemetery.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Vine Grove Methodist Church
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: View of front and right side of Vine Grove Methodist Church building in Dayton, Tennessee.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Women; Churches; Spies; Spying

United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865; Tennessee - History -- Civil War, 1861-1865; United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865 -- Participation, Female; United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865 -- Women; Espionage
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This is the oldest church in Dayton. During the Civil War, it was used to incarcerate women accused of being spies, sometimes referred to as the ""Rhea County Spartans."" They were held in the church, then transported to Chattanooga where they were released upon their promise to disband and cease activity. The building burned at an unknown date after November 29, 1885, and was replaced. See Bettye J. Broyles' Churches and Schools of Rhea County, Tennessee (F443 .R4 B74) p. 105-106.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Looking Back At Tennessee Photograph Collection

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Carnton Mansion, McGavock residence, in Franklin, Tennessee
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Front and left side view of the McGavock family Carnton Plantation residence in Franklin, Tennessee.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Mansions; Trees; Dwellings; Architectural elements; Porches
Carnton Mansion (Franklin, Tenn.); Historic buildings -- Tennessee -- Williamson County; McGavock family; McGavock, Randal, 1766-1844; McGavock, John, 1815-1893
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Carnton, built largely in the Greek Revival style, was a profitable, large-scale farming operation established in 1826 by former mayor of Nashville, Randal McGavock. When John and Carrie McGavock lived in the home in 1864 during the Battle of Franklin, it served as the largest field hospital in the area. Following the Battle of Franklin, the bodies of four dead Confederate generals--Patrick Cleburne, John Adams, Otho F. Stahl and Hiram B. Granbury--lay on Carntons back porch for a few hours.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee Department of Conservation Photograph Collection, 1937-1976

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Gallant Rescue of the Fair Spy at Shelbyville, Tenn."
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Line drawing entitled "Gallant Rescue of the Fair Spy at Shelbyville, Tenn." Depicts two Civil War officers on horseback surrounded by soldiers holding bayonets as Pauline Cushman looks on from a balcony above them.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Women; Spies; Spying

United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865; Tennessee - History -- Civil War, 1861-1865; United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865 -- Participation, Female; United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865 -- Women; Espionage
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Scattergood
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This drawing is taken from (page 337) the book "Life of Pauline Cushman the Celebrated Union Spy and Scout"written by F. L. Sarmiento, Esq in 1865. Pauline Cushman (1833-1897) was an actress and a spy for the Union Army during the Civil War. She was to be hanged in Shelbyville but was rescued by Union forces on June 27, 1863. She was later awarded the rank of Brevet-Major in the Union Army and was commended by President Lincoln for her service to the Union.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Mrs. John Jordan Crittenden
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Lithograph of Elizabeth Moss Crittenden (1803 or 4-1873). It was made from a portrait photograph taken circa 1855-65 by Matthew Brady.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Women
United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865; United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865 -- Women
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Married 3 times: Daniel Pinchbeck Wilcox (1821), William H. Ashley (1833), John Jordan Crittenden (1853). She was also Crittenden's third wife. Crittenden was a Senator, Governor of Kentucky, and twice U.S. Attorney General during the Harrison and Fillmore administrations. Two of his sons (from his first marriage) were Confederate general George Crittenden and Union general Thomas Leonidas Crittenden.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Mrs. W. A. Cheatham
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Lithograph of Adelicia Hayes Franklin Acklen Cheatham (1817-1887)
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Women; Plantation owners

United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865; Tennessee - History -- Civil War, 1861-1865; United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865 -- Women; United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865 -- Economic aspects
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Married Isaac Franklin (1839), Joseph Alexander Smith Acklen (1849), and William Archer Cheatham (1867). She and Acklen built Belmont Mansion in Nashville. After he died during the Civil War, the Confederate Army threatened to burn 2,800 bales of Adelicia's cotton; it would have financially ruined her. She transported the cotton to New Orleans and ran the Union blockade. In Liverpool, the cotton reportedly fetched $960,000 in gold. She is buried in Mt. Olivet Cemetery in Nashville.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Minute book for the Ladies' Tennessee Hospital Association of Nashville
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Small handwritten volume containing the constitution, the by-laws, and the minutes of the Tennessee Hospital Association--alternately known as the Ladies' Hospital Association of Nashville, the Ladies' Tennessee Hospital Association, and the Nashville Tennessee Hospital Association. The Association was preparing for the opening of a fourth hospital in Confederate Nashville when the volume comes to an end and Nashville falls to Federal forces.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Civil wars; Women

United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865; Tennessee -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865; United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865 -- Participation, Female; United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865 -- Women
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Tennessee Hospital Association
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Formed on August 1, 1861, this Nashville-based association sought to provide aid and assistance to sick and wounded soldiers throughout the Confederacy by taking donations of money and items, sewing soldiers' clothing and necessary items, supplying hospitals and staffing them as nurses, maintaining hospital registers, and raising money through staging events. Mrs. Frances B. Fogg served as the first President; Mrs. Dr. Shelby was the first V.P., and Mrs. William Cooper was the first Secretary.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Nannie E. Haskins diary entry, February 22, 1863
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Nannie E. Haskins diary entry about the 131st anniversary of George Washington's birth. She believes Washington would have supported the South. She praises Confederate President Jefferson Davis and ends the entry with a disparaging joke about U. S. President Abraham Lincoln.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Nannie E. Haskins diary entry, March 2, 1863
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Nannie E. Haskins diary entry in which she says that she cannot study because of the sound of constant canon fire. She surmises that the Confederates are trying to recapture Fort Donelson. She also says that she is disgusted with the color blue and never wants to see anything blue again.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Nannie E. Haskins diary entry, March 13, 1863
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Nannie E. Haskins diary entry in which she mentions Confederate Major General Earl Van Dorn's victory at the Battle of Thompson's Station. She also describes going to visit two Confederate prisoners of war from the 14th Tennessee Infantry Regiment to learn news of her brother, who was also with the 14th Tennessee and also a prisoner of war.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Nannie E. Haskins diary entry, 1863 April 26
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: It is a Sunday and Nannie writes of wagons and teams being pressed into service for the Yankees. In addition, the Yankees are trying to make everyone (including the women) take the oath of allegiance. Parties are being planned (i.e. Queen of the May) and Nannie thinks it is not the time for parties. A Col. Brewer is recovering from a shoulder wound and two Yankees named Boone and Busby came by to talk to him at Mrs. Forbes home where he is recuperating.

Brewer is recovering from a shoulder wound and two Yankees named Boone and Busby came by to talk to him at Mrs. Forbes home where he is recuperating.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Nannie Haskins diary entry, 1863 May 12
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: It is Tuesday and gunboats are visible on the Cumberland River from Nannie's home. Gen. Joe Hooker is beaten; however, Gen. Stonewall Jackson is severely and A. P. Hill is slightly wounded. Nannie wants word from her brother. She hopes that no bad news is coming about him. Marion Drane, Jane Ward have recently spent the night. Florence Johnson came in the morning & stayed until evening.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Williams, Nannie Haskins, 1846-1930; Clarksville (Tenn.) -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865; Tennessee -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865 -- Personal narratives, Confederate; Montgomery County (Tenn.) -- Social life and customs -- 19th century

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Nannie Haskins diary entry, 1863 May 17
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: It is Sunday and Stonewall Jackson is dead. After Jackson's death & the wounding of A. P. Hill, Nannie has great difficulty when she sees a Yankee. Aunt Harriet had a baby girl named Sidy [sic]. Nannie's father brought her a guitar & she will soon begin lessons. Gen. Rosencrans' order # 48 requires the taking of the oath for men and ladies over the age of 15 or to go south. Nannie writes she will not take the oath or go south unless she wants to. Yankees take possession of property of those who go south.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Nannie Haskins diary entry, 1863 May 30
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: It is Saturday and they have forced Nannie to sign the parole of honor [oath]. She regrets it. Her father does not have the funds to support her if she was sent south. He sends any extra money to her brother who is fighting in the war. Rumors abound about the state of the war. Vicksburg is not captured. Tilghman is reported killed. Valandigham [sic - Clement Laird Vallandigham] is arrested and sent South.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Nannie Haskins diary entry, 1863 July 12
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: It is Sunday and brother Ben was captured the first day of fighting at Gettysburg. Nannie thinks that those prisoners who are able to write to their family should at least mention other captured prisoners as well. Ed Bringhurst did so. Ben Hering is reported to have died at Lebanon just a few days ago. Ben Hering had rejoined Morgan. Yesterday was Mr. Block's birthday. Guests included Ma & Nannie, Mrs. Lettie, Mollie & Willie, Mesrs. Vance, Coats & George Faxon. "The Lady of Lyons" was given to Nannie.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Nannie Haskins diary entry, 1863 July 19
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Mr. & Mrs. Rust of Hopkinsville visited the Haskins in Clarksville. Mrs. Rust's brother has been taken prisoner. However, he has been sent elsewhere. Mr. Rust says Hopkinsville is a perfect despotism. Willie Settle, Sallie Lewis & Nannie went on horse-back to Nannie's Uncle Egbert. The family received a letter from Brother who is a prisoner at Fort Delaware. Theo. Hartman, also a prisoner, in a letter to George Faxon listed as dead - Willie McCullouch, wounded - Charley Mitchell & Irwin Beaumont.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Nannie Haskins diary entry, 1863 July 24
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Nannie can hear the groans of soldier from a nearby Federal hospital. Sick & wounded are no longer enemies. Mrs. Sears of Hopkinsville stopped for a visit going South to visit her husband, who had to leave Hopkinsville because of his Southern principles. Mrs. Phil Poindexter introduced her sister, Mrs. Fry, who is staying at the Spurrier Hotel. Mrs. Fry's husband is Major Fry, a paymaster [Union] in Washington, that has been ordered to California. Family received a letter from brother Ben.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Nannie Haskins diary entry, 1864 June 12
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Recounts Mr. Pollard taking her to his house for a visit with Frank Williamson [cousin], Grand Ma & little Lennie. Later at her home Mr. & Mrs. Block, Messrs. Simms & David B. & Alice Rice came to tea. Ice cream, strawberries & cake were served. A letter came from her brother. There was a concert on Friday. Nannie thought it was a poor one.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Nannie Haskins diary entry, 1864 July 4
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Nannie writes about the happiness of previous 4th of July celebrations. She writes that it is now desecrated. The Negroes and Yankees are having a big picnic. She will visit with Jamie & Heather to lift her sad feelings.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Nannie Haskins diary entry, 1864 July 14
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Nannie writes of the fighting around Washington City and the capture of [Major]-Gen. [William B.] Franklin by rebels. Pa' & Ma' Finley go to attend a man & wife who were shot by robbers. Every day she hears of something that would have startled her 4 years a go. Today these events merely get a passing thought. War has hardened people. The Small Pox is once more in town. Andrew Ewing is dead. Prisoner Gen. [James J.] Archer sent to Charleston to be put under Confederate.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Nannie Haskins Diary entry, 1864 October 28
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Nannie Haskins diary entry describing her social engagements during the Civil War in Clarksville. Haskins briefly mentions 4000 union refugees arriving in Clarksville from East Tennessee which she charaterizes as, "Mostly union cowards." She aslo mentions that "they" are teacing negro schools in local Methodist and Cumberland church basements.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Nannie Haskins Diary entry with a poem entitled, "To the Girls Over the Lines" by John W. Faxon
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: An undated Nannie E. Haskins diary entry, situated between October 29th and November 3rd of 1864 in the diary, recounting a poem entitled, "To the Girls Over the Lines", by a John W. Faxon. The poem warns young Confederate women against flirtations with Union men. Finally, in a partial entry from November 3rd, Haskins mentions that someone she knows named Zack was arrested for "throwing at a little-devil of a negro."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Nannie Haskins diary entry, 1864 December 5
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The entry is written just after the Confederate loss at the Battle of Franklin on November 30, 1864. However, Nannie writes as if it was a victory for Hood based on reports that they have received in Clarksville. She also noted the slight wounding of friends Theo. Miller, Willie Cooper and Greenfield Quarter. Three thousand Yanks arrived near Clarksville from Johnsonville and spent most of a day crossing the river. Nannie had hoped that Forrest would catch them.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Nannie Haskins diary entry, 1865 March 22
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The entry states that the "negroes" are celebrating Lincoln's birthday [actually February 12, 1809]. She descibes Lincoln as "the savior of the blacks."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Nannie Haskins diary entry, 1865 March 28
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Several speeches were delivered to the Negroes at their last celebration. One was from Col. Smith and another was from Jim Read. Nannie writes of a saying going around about green, black, lime & sassafras tea. It ends with "But I love Liber-ty." The family has had visits from Ritchie Poindexter and Charlie Rochester. Nannie received a letter from Capt. Rochester (her cousin). Major Owen, Cousin Logan and St. Adams have gone to Dixie. Walter Lance and Sallie Ready were married on Saturday.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Nannie Haskins diary entry, 1865 April 17
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Richmond fell on the 4th. General Lee surrendered on the 9th. Abraham Lincoln was shot on the 14th. Booth was the murdereer. These great events made April of 1865 the greatest of the war. At the Episcopal Church on Easter Mr. Ringgold & a lady doctress [doctor] had a loud verbal exchange over the red & white altar flowers. As she added a blue ribbon & made them red, white & blue. Letters were received from Capt. Rochester, Corbett, and Jack Anderson; however, none from brother.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Nannie Haskins diary entry, 1865 April 30
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Gen. Jo. E. Johnson has surrendered. The assassin of Lincoln, Booth, is reported as killed. Dick Johnson, Polk Johnson, Billy Green, William Daniel, Bob Moore and several have been parolled and have returned home. Brother not home as yet.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Nannie Haskins diary entry, 1865 May 8
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Soldiers are still coming home. However, the family has not heard from Brother. All commands have surrendered except Kirby Smith [he surrenders on May 26, 1865]. Nannie bemoaned the loss of the Confederacy. She declared that Davis had made some melancholy mistakes. She also blamed Hind [may mean Thomas C. Hindman] for letting Sherman pass through the South. She prayed for Davis and his cabinet.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Nannie Haskins diary entry, 1865 May 24
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This is Nannie's nineteenth birthday. She describes herself as "getting old, old, so old." Brother still has not come home as of yet. Jimmie Lockert, Mr. Wilson, Mr. Holtsman, Mr. Bert Beall, Mr. Prunskey [sic] and cousin Logan came for tea. A good many soldiers have called. The Cars [sic] have not been down as the river has risen. Mrs. Winnifred came today.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Nannie Haskins diary entry, 1865 July 18
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Nannie reports that Brother came home last evening. He left Lynchburg on Monday and has been traveling ever since. He is quite thin. Junior Beaumont came home on Thursday. He looks quite well to have sustained such a severe wound. Junior did not know of Florence's marriage to a Yankee. He is very distressed about her behavior. Last night Nannie's Pa was sent to see Aunt Lucy Beaumont, who is ill.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Nannie E. Haskins Diary, 1863-1917
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Civil wars; Women
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Williams, Nannie E. Haskins, 1846-1930
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Nannie E. Haskins (1846-1930) was born in Clarksville, the daughter of E.B. and Tennessee Stark Williamson Haskins. In 1870, she married Henry Philips Williams.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lucy Virginia French diary entry, February 16, 1862
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: February 16, 1862, diary entry - LVF writes about it young children's views of the Yankees and states that Tennessee is now invaded, and every man will be called out to defend her soil. She writes of visiting; weather (snow on Valentine's Day); Federal gun-boats maiking a "reconnoisance" up the Tennessee River; Battle of Fort Donelson; her children Jessie, Bouse (Walter) & Ting (Mary); and knitting a pink & white Mariposa (scarf) for herself.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Civil wars; Women

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lucy Virginia French diary entry, February 22, 1862
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: February 22 1862, diary entry - LVF writes of the Northern victory at Fort Donelson and tells that Nashville has been surrendered to the Union (actual date Feb. 25, 1862). Gens. Floyd & Pillow escaped Fort Donelson with some troops, but Buckner is a prisoner. "A rumor as been heard that our army would fall back to Chattanooga! I think they had better if Johnson is to command them, fall down into Mexico at once, and be done with it." "My children are well -- my husband is still with us."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lucy Virginia French diary entry, March 2, 1862
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: March 2, 1862 diary entry - LVF writes that the Federals have taken possession of Nashville. She did not go to church as Mrs. Spurlock had borrowed the buggy to go to Murfreesboro to see her husband. Gen. Buell made a speech to the Nashville citizens. Harris has called out the militia, and every man is obliged to go. Cousin John attended attened one and it was resolved that no organization could go on here, now, as we are all under Lincoln rule. Mollie & Jimmie left in the morning [Mar. 5] for Mississippi

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lucy Virginia French diary entry, March 9, 1862
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: March 9, 1862, diary entry- Grandma Lyons calls the occupied city of Nashville Yankee Land and Lincolndom. Rumors abound - Nashville blockade has been lifted and Nashville now has connection with Louisville and Cincinnati so that goods, salt & coffee, etc. are plentiful. LVF reading "Mount Vernon & its Association" in hopes that the history of our former revolution would cheer her.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lucy Virginia French diary entry, March 30, 1862
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: March 30, 1862, diary entry - States that they have been cut off from all communication with either North or South. On Sunday last our mail stopped - the train being taken off to prevent its falling into the hands of the Yankees. "I was sitting in the parlor with Mrs. Armstrong - when I saw an armed force coming up the road - we knew they were Yankess, but all went out on the portico to look at them." "I think only of my domestic affairs, my children - flowers - and chickens."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lucy Virginia French diary entry, April 20, 1862
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: April 20, 1862, diary entry - discusses the battle at Corinth, or rather Pittsburg Landing - but states that Andy Johnson will allow nothing favorable to the South to be published in Nashville. "The Federals are in possession of Huntsville and the R.R. as far as Stevenson. Savage's Regiment has gone to Corinth."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lucy Virginia French diary entry, May 4, 1862
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: May 4, 1862, diary entry - States that I never could have imagined it possible for one to live in the midst of a revolution and know so little of the real manner in which it is conducted; we feel the effects of war - yet we see but little of it[s] modus operandi. Last week I had my house cleaned from top to bottom, the yard also is cleaned and arranged for the summer and everything looks delightfully fresh and smiling.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lucy Virginia French diary entry, May 18, 1862
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: May 18, 1862, diary entry - "He[Lincoln] considers the rebellion crushed. Beauregard has ordered the drestruction of cotton, sugar, and molasses .." "During the past week I have had the children with me all the time deciding that they must not on any account make associates of the negros. I put Martha to working out--I teach them constantly--something--devoting myself to them exclusively. It is hard work--very confining--sometimes making me exceedingly nervous--but it is my duty--and that is sufficient"

"During the past week I have had the children with me all the time deciding that they must not on any account make associates of the negros. I put Martha to working out--I teach them constantly--something--devoting myself to them exclusively. It is hard work--very confining--sometimes making me exceedingly nervous--but it is my duty--and that is sufficient"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lucy Virginia French diary entry, June 15, 1862
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: June 15, 1862, diary entry - Discusses the Union Army taking food and horses. "I venture tp write a little in this brief journal though I may have to burn it ere long--As a perfect reign of terror is upon us. On Thursday last--the 12th, a force of between 4 and 5 thousand Federals, passed us, going into McMinnville--Hunting Starns--they said. There were 8 regiments--a large body of cavalry and 10 to 12 pieces of artillery. The train occupied about 4 hours in passing."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lucy Virginia French diary entry, June 22, 1862
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: June 22, 1862, diary entry--"The 'reconoissance in force' which we had thought were moving on to Chattanooga--went only 38 miles across in the direction of Pikeville, and then returned. I presume they were in reality hunting Starns--it is said they heard he was up here in the mountains somewhere, fortifying--and they came to dislodge him. They tore up everything at Mr. Betty's--broke all the furniture--ruined the garden and even tore to pieces Mrs. B's clothing."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lucy Virginia French diary entry, 1862 July 6
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Begins the passage on Sunday in bed and unwell - past week reading, sewing and teaching the children - pleasant moonlight rides with Darlin'. Letter from Mollie about Jimmy being in Vicksburg with his regiment. - Writes of McClellan's defeat before Richmond [probably Pennisula Campaign and Seven Days' Battles]. Then writes of a large cavalry force at Altamont (Forrest) coming across to march to Nashville. Ends the passage with a letter from Aunt Martha and the news that Lide has a two month old baby.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lucy Virginia French diary entry, 1862 July 17
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Passage begins, "It is all over -- and a glorious victory remains with the South!" L.V.F. goes on to describe General Crittenden and men being made prisoners by General Forrest and his men. 13 wagons of supplies captured [1st Battle of Murfreesboro]. Dr. Armstrong made a prisoner and released. [Reference is to Dr. John B. Armstrong, an Unionist.] A captive banner was shown to L. V. F. It had belonged to the 9th Michigan Infantry. L.V. F. received a letter from Lide whose baby's name is Lucy Virginia.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lucy Virginia French diary entry, 1862 July 27
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: L.V.F. discusses Forrests forces and a Federal force of about 4000-5000 in the vicinity of Manchester. The children walked with Mammy and Martha to visit Grandma Lyon. They returned highly pleased, but tired. She had a letter from Lide, written in May, in a round about way. It was sent to Margaret Rankin. Also had a letter from M. Rankin written to Mrs. Read, giving an account of the doings of the Federal troops in Sequatchie Valley and "Brute Butler" [Major General Benjamin F. Butler].

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lucy Virginia French diary entry, 1862 August 10
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: L.V.F. is relieved that her husbands birthday means he is now too old to be drafted into military service. She compares the Federal troops to an Egyptian plague from the Bible because of their rough foraging for provisions. Cooper [one of the slaves] ran off with an Ohio regiment. L.V.F. presumes that Lide thinks all this is a "come il faut" [necessary, proper].

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lucy Virginia French diary entry, 1862 August 25
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: L.V.F.: "I have drawn a long breath for the first time in 3 weeks - a long deep sigh of satisfaction and relief, - the Yankees are gone! A few straggling thieves may remain but the army is now gone as far as we are concerned. Thank God! Thank God! And may He in His goodness and mercy grant that they never visit us again! Everything is very dry -- we need rain badly, Our people will have to bestir themslves now to get enough together to keep us through the winter - Bacon is 37 1/2 cents per pound."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lucy Virginia French diary entry, August 31, 1862
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: L.V.F. writes about Yankees roughly foraging for food and the wholesale destruction that accompanied this until the Col. [her husband] went to the home where a Major was quartered which helped for a while. She further writes of "masterly inactivity" of the Confederate Army and Lawson Hills distillery being torn down with all the brandy taken. She does not know what they will have left to eat in the winter.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: L.V.F. writes about Yankees roughly foraging for food and the wholesale destruction that accompanied this until the Col. [her husband] went to the home where a Major was quartered which helped for a while. She further writes of "masterly inactivity" of the Confederate Army and Lawson Hills distillery being torn down with all the brandy taken. She does not know what they will have left to eat in the winter.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lucy Virginia French diary entry, September 3, 1862
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: L.V.F. diary entry Yankees continued to forage roughly about the area. I judge that about 30,000 men have left this place and Hickory Creek this morning - Thomas division - Woods to [sic] - and Nelsons - and this is a better riddance for which I know the heart of this community (a few tories excepted) is overflowing with thankfulness and joy.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lucy Virginia French diary entry, September 5, 1862
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: he & "Darlin' [husband] planned to ride horses [Black & Gray Tilly] into town to see Mrs. Rowan. However they found out that would not be posssible. Sam Pennebaker grew excitied as he spoke of the way in which things had been carried on at his house during his absence (it was there they found the arms, & I learned that the place was literally ruined & the house so guarded that they would not allow even Armstrong to pass in to see "Button's" sick child,)."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lucy Virginia French diary entry, September 14, 1862
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: L.V.F writes a great deal of local gossip and that Andy Johnson and Buell & staff had a desperate "flare-up." Andy got drunk & made a speech at the Capitol & an ass of himself, at one & the same time. He told Buell that "his bones should bleach on those rocks" - to which Buell replied that he did not intend to stand at Nashville, but that if he, (Andy) patriotically desired his bones to bleach there, nothing could be easier to him, (Andy) or more agreeable to himself (Buell).

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lucy Virginia French diary entry, September 21, 1862
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: L.V.F. writes the week has been a quiet, yet a busy one for her. The weather has been fine, & she has been busy all the week in putting up peaches -- What the Yankees left. The war news this week has been a confirmation of rumors. Last Thursday[9/18] was appointed by President Davis, as a day of thanksgiving and prayer, for the victories in Ky. at Richmond, and on the battle field of Manassas.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lucy Virginia French diary entry, September 28, 1862
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: L.V.F. writes of arranging the children's clothes for winter and receiving a letter from Mollie stating that she is soon coming for a visit and that Jimmie [her husband] has resigned from the cavalry and gone into the ordiance department at the same rank since his health is so delicate. Also that Henry French has been arrested by the Southerners for selling cotton to the Yankees. $12,00 was taken from him at the time of his arrest.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lucy Virginia French diary entry, October 7, 1862
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: L.V.F. writes thatYankees intended to burn up this end of town because it was illuminated when Forrest brought the prisoners up from Murfreesboro. The illumination was because Gen. Forrest had requested that the citizens have water set out all along the route for the prisoners and the citizens had done so - setting out pails and tubs of water with lights near them - so that they might see to drink it. She also discusses the Lincolns and refers to them as common as pig-tracks."

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: L.V.F. writes thatYankees intended to burn up this end of town because it was illuminated when Forrest brought the prisoners up from Murfreesboro. Forrest had requested that the citizens have water set out all along the route for the prisoners and the citizens had done so - setting out pails and tubs of water with lights near them - so that they might see to drink it. She also discusses the Lincolns and refers to them as common as pig-tracks."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lucy Virgina French diary entry dated, November 2, 1862
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "Darlin" planning a new home in the octagonal shape. LVF wonders if it is folly to think of it with bacon 50 a pound, flour $15 a barrel and calico $1 per yard. No provisons for travellers in Chattanooga. A clipping in the diary from the October 20, 1862 edition of the Chattanooga Rebel discusses Union soldiers taking a cow from the sick mother of a 3 week old baby. When the mother asked that they leave one cow for the babe to have milk, one of the soldiers took the babys bottle and broke it.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lucy Virgina French diary entry, December 7, 1862
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Describes coldest day of the season 18 degrees outside and snow. The southern army is at Murfreesboro & Shelbyville. The Yankees are at Nashville. Bouse, who had been barefoot all of the fall, got his shoes last night. L. V. F. is as good as barefoot yet she cannot get any shoes as the 20th Alabama are being furnished w/ shoes, clothing, etc. Every species of clothing is very dear. The men from Alabama have plenty of captured yankee clothing taken in Ky. They do not wear it but they will sell it.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lucy Virginia French diary entry, December 28, 1862
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Santa Claus couldnt get thro the pickets, - Jessie wanted to know why the old fellow couldnt go to his Quartermaster and get him a pass? They seemed to enjoy their Christmas quite as well as usual however, notwithstanding that Santa Claus was blockaded. There is news of troops movements [The Battle of Stones River was fought December 31,1862 to January 2, 1863.]

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lucy Virginia French diary entry, December 31, 1862
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Battle of Stones River was to decide whether or not the French family were still to have a home, or be sent forth as refugees to find a sojourning place in a land of strangers. Cannonading was heard in the direction of Murfreesboro. Everything in the shape of a soldier went into it. Darlin' promised to take L. V. F. down in a few days [to Murfreesboro] if the Yankees retreated to Nashville.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lucy Virginia French diary entry, January 4, 1863
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: News of the great victory at Murfreesboro gladdened their Hearts - and they counted over the spoils - as follows - 6000 prisoners, 3000 mules, 40 cannon, quantities of ordnance & ammunition - a good deal of coffee etc. for the sick, burnt six hundred wagons - and killed Yankees in some places 10 to 1. Our loss in killed & wounded 5000. One of the killed was Capt. Spurlock. His father was there-He had gone down with a waggon [sp] to carry the boys Christmas things-& he brought back the body of his son!

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: continued
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: News of the great victory at Murfreesboro gladdened their Hearts - and they counted over the spoils - as follows - 6000 prisoners, 3000 mules, 40 cannon, quantities of ordnance & ammunition - a good deal of coffee etc. for the sick, burnt six hundred wagons - and killed Yankees in some places 10 to 1. Our loss in killed & wounded 5000. One of the killed was Capt. Spurlock. His father was there-He had gone down with a waggon [sp] to carry the boys Christmas things-& he brought back the body of his son!

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lucy Virginia French diary entry, January 13, 1863
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Tells of one of Morgans men coming, William B. Loyd, by the house to ask to use it as the headquarters for Gen. [Roy S.] Cluke. Darlin' would not consent at all. Loyd asked permission to remain all night-which was granted. Next morning the Col. [Darlin'] went with him to Gilbert's where headquarters were obtained. The city is full of bad women. They are at hotels & in private houses living with the officers & passing for their wives. She states that the place too is full of female spies & detectives.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: French, L. Virginia (Lucy Virginia), 1825-1881 -- Diaries; United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865 -- Personal narratives; Tennessee -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865 -- Personal narratives

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lucy Virginia French diary entry, January 19, 1863
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The same night he was here I had a sick soldier-one of Morgans men, and a comrade who attended him. The name of the sick one was Rice-he was 15 years of age. We have bread & meat-wheat coffee & sassafras tea-a little milk & a very little butter. Our situation here is one of great anxiety & uncertainty.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lucy Virginia French diary entry, 1863 February 8
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Begins with ball preparations and her disapointment of some officers' behavior. Next writes of very strong storms in the night. Finally she writes that Morgans men that are behaving badly, and he is "losing character by the way they go on stealing pressing burning etc. The old farmers round say they had quite as leave have the Yankees in here. They have torn up a great deal, but still I feel secure to what I would if there were Yankees about us. Heaven grant that they may never get in here again!"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lucy Virginia French diary entry, 1863 February 15
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In this entry Lucy writes of a visit from General Morgan and his wife. Lucy liked Mrs. Morgan although she was not brillant. There was a Ball with meager food and clothes that were reworked.. She writes that events in Vicksburg & Charleston are rumored to be coming and of importance.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lucy Virginia French diary entry, 1863 March 11
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In this entry Lucy Virgiria writes of attending church & hearing Dr. Hopson preach, who was Gen. Morgans chaplin. She liked the sermon. Her three children began school again and the school room required much prepapration. Her children complained that they had not enough at lunch. Lucy Virginia prepared to have Gen. Morgan & his wife to dinner. Mollie's husband Jimmie wrote that there would be another attempt by the Yankess on Vicksburg.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lucy Virginia French diary entry, 1863 April 26
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In the entry Darlin comes back from a visit to town and announces that the Yankees are coming again. The Yankees burned the stables; however, Darlin was able to save about half of one poultry house, by ripping off roofing and planking to stop the fire's progress. Many of Lucy's kitchen items were carried off as well as two young horses. She writes of a practically bare parlor and all of their best belongings away now except for her piano.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: continued
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In the entry Darlin comes back from a visit to town and announces that the Yankees are coming again. The Yankees burned the stables; however, Darlin was able to save about half of one poultry house, by ripping off roofing and planking to stop the fire's progress. Many of Lucy's kitchen items were carried off as well as two young horses. She writes of a practically bare parlor and all of their best belongings away now except for her piano.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lucy Virginia French diary entry, 1863 June 10
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In this entry Lucy Virginia writes of robbers attacking and threatening Beersheba Springs. Apparently robberies have been committed on unoccupied cottages where blankets, bedding, china and clothing have been taken. However the area is well guarded. She writes of having been at Beersheba Springs a month and writing only four or five hours a day. The remainder of her time is spent in sewing for the children, reading and sleeping.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lucy Virginia French diary entry, 1863 July 12
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In thie entry Lucy Virginia writes of Mrs A. going out her the front door and meeting a soldier who demanded 15 lbs. of bread. He proved to be part of a Confederate scout operation of about 20 men. Lucy Vriginia writes of hiding in a canister the manuscript of her book along with other valuables. Lucy states that she is prepared to lose everything before this war is over. She further writes that Vicksburg has certainly fallen by the garrison being straved out.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lucy Virginia French diary entry, 1863 July 21
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In this entry Lucy Virginia writes of being awoken by men with horses in front of the house. They had come to arrest the Colonel and Mr. Henderson. Lucy further writes of knowing whom to thank for this -- the Unionists of McMinnville. She also writes that Charleston has fallen, Yakees are in Chattanooga and Lee was driven out of Pennsylvania with great losses.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lucy Virginia French diary entry, 1863 July 22
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In this entry Lucy Vriginia writes of the Colonel and Mr. Henderson's homecoming after being made to take the oath. Mr. Henderson's bond was $5,000 and the Colonel's bond was $25,000. She writes of dozens going in daily to take the oath and that 5 young ladies may be arrested as well.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lucy Virginia French diary entry, 1863 July 26
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In this long entry Lucy Virginia writes of the terrible looting of the cottages and hotel by the mounatin people. She even compares it to the French Revolution reign of terror on a small scale without the flow of blood.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lucy Virginia French diary entry, 1863 October 12
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: French begins by writing of an inconvenient situation (a boil) which obliged her to lie on her back at all times. She describes Confederate Gen. Wheeler's capture of about 800 Union troops in McMinnville and Wheeler's opening of their commissary stores to the people. Afterwards the Yankees passed back through McMinnville and tried to make eveyone return those stores that Wheeler had dispersed. Finally she writes that the "Abolition Nashille Union" newspaper "exalts" that Warren County has been desolated.

Wheeler's capture of about 800 Union troops in McMinnville and Wheeler's opening of their commissary stores to the people. Afterwards the Yankees passed back through McMinnville and tried to make eveyone return those stores that Wheeler had dispersed. Finally she writes that the "Abolition Nashille Union" newspaper "exalts" that Warren County has been desolated.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lucy Virginia French diary entry, 1863 December 27
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Lucy Virginia writes of 2 Union officers wanting to search the house befoe Christmas for Beersheba [Hotel] property. They left convinced that they were duped by the persons who sent them. All Christmas gifts were homemade and consisted of cakes, apples, hoods, gloves, needle-books, cuffs and candy sent from Mollie.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lucy Virginia French diary entry, 1864 February 28
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Lucy Virginia writes of fires on the mountains all around and that at night the fires look like a marching army. She had a note from Mollie about the high cost of items such as butter $4 or $5 a pound and so on. She next writes that Longstreet has Knoxville, Bob French was killed near Sparta and her beloved Grandmother died in her 97th year.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lucy Virginia French diary entry, 1864 March 20
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: French was very ill with a headache from Thursday through Saturday. She has been reading aloud "Husks" by Marian Harland and has also begun Raids and Romance of Morgan and his Men by Sallie Rochester Ford. She did not enjoy the first as much as "The Rejected Wife" by Ann S. Stephens. Another visit from Rebel and Yankee forces and rumors abound about the state of the war. Newspapers are purported to be surpressed.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lucy Virginia French diary entry, 1864 March 30
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: During a cold, damp day two brothers are disinterring their brother, a rebel killed in the last skirmish that Mr. Dugan had found and buried. Darlin' is not home yet. Daughter Jessie has a swollen face and complains at night. Rumors abound. France has recognized the Confederacy and Charleston has been abandoned by the Yankees. Gen. Grant has been ordered to replace Gen. Meade in Virginia.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lucy Virginia French diary entry, 1864 May 22
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Col. John French & family are at Beersheba Springs in Grundy County just South of McMinnville in Warren County. Some old friends are back at Beersheba Springs. The Col. John Armflelds and the Scotts. Mr. Armfield brought some Dr. J. Hostetter's Stomach Bitters [47 % alcohol] for Lucy Virginia. [Col. Armfield was responsible for some of Beersheba Springs growth.] The papers are full of battles on or near the Rapidan River in Virginia. News from Georgis is that the Yankees have Dalton.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lucy Virginia French diary entry, 1864 September 11
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: On the Thursday before a large body of Rebels passed through. They belonged to [Gen. Joseph] Wheeler. As it was early fall peaches were still on the trees. French was busy preserving peaches, putting up tomatoes and so on but had no vinegar to make pickles or ketchups. While she is not suffering from headaches she is suffering from acidity of the stomach and indigestion. French is mistaken for the Colonels daughter by a Rebel as she peels peaches on the back porch.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lucy Virginia French diary entry, 1864 October 30
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: French writes of a feeling of sadness and the long and terrible strain caused by the war. The 1864 presidential election is very much on her mind. She wants to leave the country if Abe and Andy are elected. All the things from Beersheba Springs are being brought down. The Armsfields have gone down to Sumner County. She has commenced quilting skirts and making winter clothes for the children and servants despite still suffering from her headaches. The men spend their time running after war news .

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lucy Virginia French diary entry, 1864 November 6
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: After a stormy night French is grateful for shelter, warmth and children that are well. However, she is still preoccupied with the 1864 presidential election. On the home front she is cutting out clothing, making comforts, shirts and has apple butter to eat. In addition sweet pumpkins are being dried for use in the spring. Thread is difficult to come by so she is compelled to use home-made thread that is dyed with bark.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lucy Virginia French diary entry, 1864 November 20
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1864 presidential election is over & LV is surprised that there is no hue & cry over the election either for or against. She received a letter from Lide. She & family spent the summer at Mackinaw & Cheboygan & returned to Memphis in October. Col. has been talking with Dr. Warder about publishing her Southern Sketch Book. He thinks there might be some money in it. LV does not think so but they are welcome to the mss. Col.'s other plan is to mortgage the house, sell off their household goods & go to PA.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lucy Virginia French diary entry, 1864 December 25
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The cause of the South has gone down. Yesteday Fench and Martha worked all day making cakes, molasses candy, egg-nog, etc. for the children. She had a difficult time finding items for the children's stockings. She had a set of tiny coffee cups and saucers which they had never seen or forgotten for the little girls and put in the boy's stocking paper, pen, pencils and some greenback. The children were very pleased. Mollie came for Christmas. They heard of Hood's retreat in the evening.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lucy Virginia French diary entry, 1865 January 1
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: On the first day of the year 1865 LVF is very down in her mood. She believes that the weather is becoming colder than it was when she married & came to McMinnville. Mollie has made a wreath of evergreens to place on Cap Spurlock's grave as it is the anniversary of his death. The feeding, clothing & educating of her children are weighing on LVF. She wonders how it will be done. She writes of understanding Maggie Tulliver of "The Mill on the Floss" by George Eliot.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lucy Virginia French diary entry, 1865 January 8
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Weather is better. Mr. Wallace plans to go to Nashville & LVF will send her letters to Lide and Mrs. Armfield with him. Coggins has just returned from Nashville with newspapers. From these Lee appears to be holding his own in Virginia & Sherman has done all he can in Georgia. LVF has been re-reading Washington Irving's "History of New York." LVF's head is occupied with trying to keep body & soul together. Col. bought 150 lbs. of beef for $18 (with plenty of bones) & molasses is $1.50 per gallon.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lucy Virginia French diary entry, 1865 January 24
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Cold snap has brought the temperature to 15. LVF is bringing in the wood for her fires herself as they have some bad wood. Her shoulders need to be broad & strong but they are not. LVF did not write of their anniversary on the 12th as it was dull as all their days are now. Col. & Mr. Humble were busy all week tearing down a town ivery stable for the timbers. Papers are full of peace rumors. In describing some of the military actions she uses the words -- mizzle, drizzle & fizzle.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lucy Virginia French diary entry, 1865 April 23
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Cold north wind yesterday, frost last night & the morning is quite chilly. Col., Mr. James Spurlock & Mr. Colville started for Nashville on Friday. They had one horse & buggy between them. LVF was reminded that on April 20, 1864, was the last time that she saw Gen. & Mrs. Morgan [Gen. Mordan died 9/4/1864]. They first heard of the assassination of Lincoln was last Tues. Rumors abounded as to whom else was killed. In Nashville 10 men were killed for rejoicing over Lincoln's death.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lucy Virginia French diary entry, 1865 May 14
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Federal army is reducing in size from resignations & mustering out of men. Quartermaster's Departments are cutting down as well. No one from the town or vicinity has made it back to the area as yet. If they come back by May 22, it will be 4 years exactly as that was the day they all left out in 1861. LVF thinks that the Col. has too much of the Micawber in him. He thinks something will turn up. LVF writes that they are making a great to do over Petroleum, but she does not think much will come of it.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lucy Virginia French diary entry, 1865 June 26
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: LVF & Puss must do everything such as milking, making beds, setting tables, cleaning and ironing. Mollie is giving concern with her behavior. LVF's Aunt Martha wants to come to the family in the fall. As they have no conveniences LVF does not know what to tell her aunt. Mrs. Wilcher is weaving the thread for 25 yds of striped cotton for the servants. Col. has gone after tallow for candles. Star candles are selling for 25 a lb. LVF does not want to buy anything that she can do possibly do without.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lucy Virginia French diary
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Civil wars; Women
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: French, L. Virginia (Lucy Virginia), 1825-1881
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Lucy Virgina Smith French was the daughter of Mease W. and Elizabeth Parker Smith. She was born on March 16, 1825. She was married, on Jan. 12, 1853, to Col. John Hopkins French. By the time of the 1860 U.S. Census of McMinnville, Warren County, Tennessee, they had three children ages six and under, one boy and two girls. Her profession on the 1860 census is listed as "Poetess, Author." She died on March 31, 1881.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Rachel Carter Craighead diary entry dealing with Battle of Pittsburg Landing
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Handwritten entry for the date represents the Civil War diary of Rachel Carter Craighead. It addresses the news of Confederate and Federal losses at the Battle of Pittsburg Landing (or the Battle of Shiloh), the Confederate generals killed or wounded in the fight, and the reliability of the Federal occupation press.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Rachel Carter Craighead diary entry relays news of Battle of Shiloh
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Handwritten entry for the date, covering parts of two pages of this small volume representing the Civil War diary of Rachel Carter Craighead. This entry addresses the news of the Battle of Pittsburg Landing (also known as the Battle of Shiloh), the Confederate generals killed or wounded in the fight, and the reliability of the Federal occupation press. Craighead contends Confederate forces won the battle; she questions the lack of a forced Federal illumination celebration in Nashville.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Rachel Carter Craighead diary entry continues to record news of Battle of Shiloh
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Handwritten entry for the date, covering parts of two pages of this small volume representing the Civil War diary of Rachel Carter Craighead. This entry addresses first-hand news of the Battle of Pittsburg Landing (also known as the Battle of Shiloh) obtained from a person coming from Corinth that confirms the battle as a complete victory for the South. Confederate generals killed or wounded are addressed, but Craighead states the names of Federal leaders wounded or killed aren't worth recording.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Rachel Carter Craighead diary entry with personal news from Battle of Shiloh
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Handwritten entry for the date, covering parts of two pages of this small volume representing the Civil War diary of Rachel Carter Craighead. News of acquaintances having been wounded at the Battle of Shiloh (Pittsburg Landing) begins to trickle into Nashville and is recorded in Craighead's diary. She also notes female friends headed to the battlefield to tend to loved ones.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Rachel Carter Craighead diary entry describing restrictions by Federal authorities
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Handwritten entry for the date, covering parts of three pages of this small volume representing the Civil War diary of Rachel Carter Craighead. Craighead relates threatened retaliation by Federal authorities in Nashville for participation in a Confederate tableaux and for aiding the "Rebellion" in general. She also conveys the restrictions in writing of the Confederate cause to her Uncle Will, a Confederate prisoner in Columbus, Ohio.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Rachel Carter Craighead diary entry records the surrender of Island No. 10
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Handwritten entry for the date, covering parts of one page of this small volume representing the Civil War diary of Rachel Carter Craighead. Craighead relates the surrender of Island No. 10 to Federal forces and the fact that Fort Pillow was then in jeopardy from Brig. Gen. John Pope, commander of the Army of the Mississippi. She records the term ""skeddadlers"" in her diary; the word has an origin as Civil War military slang, meaning ""to run away.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Rachel Carter Craighead diary entry records encounter with 69th Ohio and graveyard visit
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Handwritten entry for the date, covering parts of one page of this small volume representing the Civil War diary of Rachel Carter Craighead. Craighead relates a visit from the 69th Ohio Volunteer Infantry, that reported from Camp Chase to Nashville on April 22nd, served provost duty in Nashville from June to December of 1862, and saw their first battle at Stone's River. Craighead's visit to the City Cemetery brought memories of her uncle's hospital stay and thoughts of a nurse's comfort to soldiers.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Rachel Carter Craighead diary entry relates tales of Federal sentries and occupation insults
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Handwritten entry for the date, covering parts of three page of this small volume representing the Civil War diary of Rachel Carter Craighead. Craighead writes of the sentries on duty outside their 6th and Union residence; men commenting the house was ""too good for Rebels""; a storekeeper refusing to change her money; and the sins of a Miss Harper, who bought bonnets to sell from New York. Craighead also refers to pictures for sale of General Simon Bolivar Buckner, prisoner at Fort Warren.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Rachel Carter Craighead diary entry, 1862 August 11
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Handwritten entry for the date, covering parts of three pages of this small volume representing the Civil War diary of Rachel Carter Craighead. Entry finds Federal soldiers searching the family home for two banners of the ""R. C. G.""--the Rock City Guards. Rachel's husband Tom is faced with Federal impressment of slaves to work on Nashville's fortifications.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Rachel Carter Craighead diary entry, 1862 September 7
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Handwritten entry for the date, covering parts of two pages of this small volume representing the Civil War diary of Rachel Carter Craighead. Entry finds residents of the city of Nashville feeling the strains of feeding Federal forces that had the potential to greatly swell with active troop movement. Rachel's grandfather as well as the Craighead family are being tapped to feed the Federal soldiers. A great amount of commotion also ensues in the streets of the city as numerous regiments come and go.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Rachel Carter Craighead diary entry, 1862 September 7
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Handwritten entry for the date, covering parts of three pages of this small volume representing the Civil War diary of Rachel Carter Craighead. Entry reveals that Rachel and her mother are making pockets in which to hide away valuables. Having endured the ransacking of their home a month before by Federal soldiers searching for flags, the women knew valuables were at risk. Pockets might be sewn into clothing and undergarments in hopes that female modesty would be honored by occupying forces.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Rachel Carter Craighead diary entry, 1862 September 7
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Handwritten entry for the date, covering parts of three pages of this small volume representing the Civil War diary of Rachel Carter Craighead. Entry reveals that Rachel and her mother are making pockets in which to hide away valuables. Having endured the ransacking of their home a month before by Federal soldiers searching for flags, the women knew valuables were at risk. Pockets might be sewn into clothing and undergarments in hopes that female modesty would be honored by occupying forces.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Rachel Carter Craighead diary entry with newspapers carrying Emancipation Proclamation
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Handwritten entry from Rachel Carter Craighead's Civil War diary. Newspaper accounts are related of General William ""Bull"" Nelson's evacuation order for women and children from Louisville. The cause is a possible Confederate attack from General Braxton Bragg and Major General George B. McClellan's victory at Antietam. McClellan's victory thwarted Lee's invasion of Maryland and gave justification for Lincoln's announcement of the preliminary Emancipation Proclamation on September 22, 1862.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Rachel Carter Craighead diary entry relating Confederate forces threatening Nashville and casualties
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Handwritten entry from Rachel Carter Craighead's Civil War diary. Craighead relates her elation at the sound of the cannons outside the city and likens the situation to the Panic of February when the city fell. The day before, Forrest and Morgan threatened Nashville in an attempt to destroy cars and locomotives with artillery and cavalry; the raiders withdrew in the face of 12,000 Union troops. Craighead is despondent as Union reinforcements enter the city as well as war casualties.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Rachel Carter Craighead diary entry, 1862 November 7
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Handwritten entry for the date, covering parts of three pages of this small volume representing the Civil War diary of Rachel Carter Craighead. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Rachel Carter Craighead diary entry with mention of brother's ill health following Perryville
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Handwritten entry from Rachel Carter Craighead's Civil War diary. Craighead notes confiscated properties in Nashville currently occupied by Federal military officials. She also relates the critical condition of her younger brother John, a Sergeant Major with the 1st Tennessee who was wounded at the Battle of Perryville on October 8, 1862; he evidently lost a leg. Born December 5, 1840, John died January 18, 1863 at Harrodsburg, Kentucky, ten miles from the site of the battle.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Handwritten entry from Rachel Carter Craighead's Civil War diary. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Rachel Carter Craighead diary entry announcing the death of her brother and her misery
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Handwritten entry from Rachel Carter Craighead's Civil War diary. Craighead announces to the reader the date and time of her younger brother John's death. John Carter was a Sergeant Major with the 1st Tennessee wounded at the Battle of Perryville on October 8, 1862. Born December 5, 1840, John died January 18, 1863 at Harrodsburg, Kentucky, ten miles from the site of the battle. His family was present during his dying days.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Rachel Carter Craighead diary entry with news of Fannie Battle
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Handwritten entry from Rachel Carter Craighead's Civil War diary. Craighead notes the two-year anniversary of the firing on Fort Sumter that touched off the war, as well as the April 1863 unsuccessful Federal effort to retake the fort. Mentioned also is the arrest of Fannie Battle and family friend Harriet Booker for spying, smuggling, and possessing a forged pass. The women were held at Camp Chase and later the Old Capitol Prison before being exchanged for Federal officers in May of 1863

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Rachel Carter Craighead diary entry mentioning arrest of numerous male Confederate sympathizers
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Handwritten entry for the date, covering one page of this small volume. Craighead notes the rumored arrest or planned arrest of five hundred Confederate sympathizers. They were to be quartered in the Penitentiary and then sent to Camp Chase for exchange for East Tennessee Unionists.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Rachel Carter Craighead diary entry with anniversary of First Tennessee off to war
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Handwritten entry for the date, covering parts of two pages. Entry finds Craighead noting the two-year anniversary of the First Tennessee Regiment, including her brother with the Rock City Guards, passing through Nashville from their induction camp, Camp Cheatham in Adams, Tennessee, on the way to the seat of war in Virginia. Newspaper accounts chart a two-month stay at Camp Cheatham for the unit, with six hours of drilling per day. The camp was named after Confederate general Benjamin F. Cheatham.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Rachel Carter Craighead diary entry with news of Overton Hotel disaster
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Handwritten entry covering one page. Craighead mentions the disastrous collapse this day of the stairs at the Overton Hotel (later Maxwell House Hotel), which housed Confederate prisoners. John Overton, Jr.'s construction of the luxury hotel was halted by the Civil War. Confederates housed troops in the ""Zollicoffer Barracks""; Federal officials would do the same before using it as a hospital, and then a prison. Numbers of killed and injured vary widely, but at least 100 prisoners were involved.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Rachel Carter Craighead diary entry, 1863 December 29
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Handwritten entry from Rachel Carter Craighead's Civil War diary. News of the burning of Rock Rest, the family's country home in Robertson County reached Craighead. The Robertson County connection came from Rachel's mother, the former Mary J. Buntin; Mary's father was John Buntin of Tanglewood Farm in Robertson County. Though subjected to fire during the Civil War, the property continued to be a summer residence and social center for decades and remained in the family for generations.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Rachel Carter Craighead diary entry, 1863 December 30-31
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Handwritten entry from Rachel Carter Craighead's Civil War diary. As Craighead absorbs the news of a family friend becoming engaged to a Federal, she recalls that 1863 held the death of her brother John. She also recalls the burning of Rock Rest, the family's country home in Robertson County and her extended absences from her husband, Tom's, side.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Rachel Carter Craighead diary entry, 1864 January 26
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Handwritten entry from Rachel Carter Craighead's Civil War diary. Craighead relates the delivery by Federal soldiers of an order to vacate the house and efforts by Mrs. Bankhead to reverse the order. General Grant had planned to set up winter headquarters in Nashville for his Army of the West, and this involved occupying the Carter Craighead residence.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Rachel Carter Craighead diary entry, 1864 February 8 & 10
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Handwritten entry from Rachel Carter Craighead's Civil War diary. Craighead relates General Grant's survey of the family parlor, where he planned to reside as he established his winter headquarters across the street. She also describes their actual meeting. Later when Grant's wife and child came to live with him, he would relocate, pay the family for their trouble, and give them an order of protection.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Rachel Carter Craighead diary entry, 1864 February 8 & 10
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Handwritten entry from Rachel Carter Craighead's Civil War diary. Craighead relates General Grant's survey of the family parlor, where he planned to reside as he established his winter headquarters across the street. She also describes their actual meeting. Later when Grant's wife and child came to live with him, he would relocate, pay the family for their trouble, and give them an order of protection.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Rachel Carter Craighead diary entry, 1864 February 12-14
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Handwritten entry from Rachel Carter Craighead's Civil War diary. Craighead relates a singular tale of a Nashville female warming to the General, as he occupies the parlor of the Carter Craighead home. It would take longer for most citizens, but the Nashville Common Council voted to extend to Grant the hospitality of the city in mid-February. Later when Grant's wife and child came to live with him, he would relocate, pay the Carter Craighead family, and give them an order of protection.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Rachel Carter Craighead diary entry, 1864 February 28
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Handwritten entry from Rachel Carter Craighead's Civil War diary. Craighead notes that General Grant's wife and child have traveled to Nashville by train to live with him. They will be relocating to the residence of Mrs. J. T. Dunlap at 2 McLemore Street in Nashville. Upon leaving, Grant returned the front door key to the family.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Rachel Carter Craighead diary entry, 1864 March 4
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Handwritten entry from Rachel Carter Craighead's Civil War diary. With the arrival of his family, Grant was relocating to the residence of Mrs. J. T. Dunlap at 2 McLemore Street. Craighead's father received a visit from Grant arranging to pay his room and board and conveying an order of protection for the family. Grant's visit was followed by that of a major insistent on securing the same rooms in the Carter Craighead home for his family; when refused, he left angry and intent on contacting Grant.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Rachel Carter Craighead diary entry, 1864 May 18, with mention of suspicious Lincoln proclamation
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Handwritten entry from Rachel Carter Craighead's Civil War diary. Craighead notes the strange nature of a Lincoln proclamation calling for 400,000 soldiers. The Official Records contains details of this forgery perpetrated by newspaperman Joseph Howard in hopes of making a profit on gold stock prices. Only two New York newspapers published the story, but it evidently made its way to Nashville. Howard was arrested. Lincoln ordered his release from Fort Lafayette Prison in August of 1864

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Rachel Carter Craighead diary entry, 1864 July 21, mentioning a trip to Louisville
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Handwritten entry from Rachel Carter Craighead's Civil War diary. Craighead mentions a trip to Louisville with family, where she encounters acquaintances heading north, shops, and stays at the Galt House. The Galt House was the location where Federal general Jefferson C. Davis shot his commanding officer, General William ""Bull"" Nelson in September of 1862.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Rachel Carter Craighead diary entry, 1864 November 8, noting African American participation in presidential election
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Handwritten entry from Rachel Carter Craighead's Civil War diary. Craighead refers to the mock elections and celebrations that blacks held in Nashville during the 1864 presidential election.. Actual elections were held that year in occupied Tennessee and Louisiana, though no electoral votes were awarded from any of the southern states. On February 25, 1867, the Tennessee Legislature gave blacks the right to vote. They officially voted in the November 1868 presidential election.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Rachel Carter Craighead diary entry, 1865 April 10, mentioning Lee's surrender
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Handwritten entry from Rachel Carter Craighead's Civil War diary. Craighead mentions that news had reached her of the surrender of General Robert E. Lee of the Army of Northern Virginia to General Ulysses S. Grant at Appomattox Courthouse on April 9, 1865. The Confederate surrenders that followed were patterned after the agreement forged at Appomattox. Craighead chose not to elaborate in her diary upon this development.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Rachel Carter Craighead diary entry, 1865 April 15, mentioning Lincoln's assassination
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Handwritten entry from Rachel Carter Craighead's Civil War diary. Craighead notes that this designated day of celebration of recent mlitary victories and the anniversary of Lincoln's call for troops in April of 1861 is overshadowed with grief upon news of the assassination of President Lincoln. Nashville's parade, concert, fireworks, and patriotic decorations are laid aside, and the city drapes in mourning.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Rachel Carter Craighead diary entry, 1865 April 17, mentioning order to drape house in mourning
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Handwritten entry from Rachel Carter Craighead's Civil War diary. Craighead notes the family received a threatening military order to drape the house in mourning for the President's death. Dry goods stores in Nashville had opened on the 15th to distribute black crepe for draping. Evidently, those who disregarded delivered orders for public displays of mourning had their buildings confiscated by the army within a matter of days.
